summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York today entered a final judgment against a defendant who was convicted of sexual battery in violation of the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Gretna, New York, alleges that, on April 6, 2015, defendant Elvin D. Villafranca and two co-defendants engaged in a sexual battery of a juvenile under the age of 13.  According to the complaint, the defendants entered into an agreement to pay a penalty of 25 years imprisonment without benefit of parole, 30 years of supervised release, and a five-year officer-and-director bar, with the option of a permanent injunction against further violations of the federal securities laws.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for New York announced criminal charges against the defendants.  On May 9, 2018, the U. S. District Judge in New York granted the SEC's request for a temporary restraining order and ordered the defendants to return to their respective homes.  Without admitting or denying the allegations of the complaint filed in the SEC, defendants consented to the entry of final judgments permanently enjoining them from future violations of Sections 5(a), 5(c), and 17(a) of The Securities Act of 1933, and ordering them to pay disgorgement of their ill-gotten gains with prejudgment interest, a civil penalty of $1,000, and an officer and director bar against them.   The court also granted the defendants' motion for a preliminary injunction, ordering the destruction of any evidence in the case, ordering a hearing on the matter, and imposing a conduct-based injunction prohibiting the defendants from further violating the charged provisions of the securities laws, including Section 10 of the Exchange Act, and Section 13(b)(5) of Exchange Act Rules 10b2-1 and 13a-11 thereunder, ordering that the defendants be barred from serving as officers or directors of a public company, and that the court will determine whether to impose a penalty based on the facts of the case.
